Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Computational Pathophysiology-Centric Medical Guidance Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is dramatically reduced preventable medical errors, which claims 250,000 lives per year and is the third leading cause of deaths. Our medical best practice guidance system is an advanced clinical decision support (CDS) technology. Like Global Positioning System (GPS) based navigation systems that transformed transportation, the guidance systems developed here will potentially fundamentally transform the implementation of medical best practices, with rapid and consistent timing of medical interventions, preventing unintended deviation from standardized medical treatment guidelines, more accurate record keeping, and improved team situation awareness. Current market reports estimate a CDS market of more than $1 billion by 2023, with stand-alone systems accounting for the greatest market share.


This I-Corps further develops a computational pathophysiology platform. Using this new computational paradigm, an informal description of the disease process in the medical text can be transformed into executable formal representations in the form of networked organ state machines and best practice state machines that can be verified against specifications and validated in clinical evaluation. The result is executable computer models and precise software that can track and records complex disease dynamics. The precise and repeatable nature of executable software model removes errors caused by subjective interpretations and memorization problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois

POR.DRECONTENT:
The unintended deviation from medical best practice is known as preventable medical error. From 1999 to 2016, the death caused by preventable medical errors rose from below 98,000 persons per year by the Institute of Medicine to 250,000 deaths per year, according to a study by Johns Hopkins.  

To help prevent unintended deviation from medical best practice, we have developed computational pathophysiology models that transform pathophysiology described in natural languages into precise software that can be specified, verified and clinically validated.  In collaboration with OSF Children's Hospital of Illinois, we have developed pediatric sepsis guidance system. In cooperation with Carle Foundation Hospital, we have developed cardiac arrest resuscitation guidance system.  Both of these two systems are in the phase of clinical evaluations.

Encouraged by the successful initial results, we considered to form a startup. To prepare for the startup, we attended I-CORP workshops.   During the workshop, we conducted a total of 101 interviews with physicians, nurses, EMT Providers, hospital administrators, and healthcare industry experts from different clinical environments, ranging from rural-area and small hospitals to research hospitals and hospital networks.  

We have learned to have successful startup in this area, we need to i) complete successful clinical evaluation first; and 2) address financial and operational concerns such as the cost of medical staff training and the integration of existing hospital systems.  We decided to defer the startup until these issues are addressed.

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2021
Modified by: Lui Sha
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The unintended deviation from medical best practice is known as preventable medical error. From 1999 to 2016, the death caused by preventable medical errors rose from below 98,000 persons per year by the Institute of Medicine to 250,000 deaths per year, according to a study by Johns Hopkins. To help prevent unintended deviation from medical best practice, we have developed computational pathophysiology models that transform pathophysiology described in natural languages into precise software that can be specified, verified and clinically validated. In collaboration with OSF Children's Hospital of Illinois, we have developed pediatric sepsis guidance system. In cooperation with Carle Foundation Hospital, we have developed cardiac arrest resuscitation guidance system. Both of these two systems are in the phase of clinical evaluations. Encouraged by the successful initial results, we considered to form a startup. To prepare for the startup, we attended I-CORP workshops. During the workshop, we conducted a total of 101 interviews with physicians, nurses, EMT Providers, hospital administrators, and healthcare industry experts from different clinical environments, ranging from rural-area and small hospitals to research hospitals and hospital networks. We have learned to have successful startup in this area, we need to i) complete successful clinical evaluation first; and 2) address financial and operational concerns such as the cost of medical staff training and the integration of existing hospital systems. We decided to defer the startup until these issues are addressed. Last Modified: 01/25/2021 Submitted by: Lui Sha
